Why oh why do you try to fool the public about the so-called 'liquid oxygen' streaming from the launch vehicles? Why can't you simply tell the public the truth? This phenomenon is NOT caused by 'liquid oxygen' but from something far older. It's extra STEAM venting off as they finish fueling the STEAM engines inside the 'rockets'. In reality, there are tiny railroad locomotives inside the 'rocket' tubes that make it go up. After all, despite all of the ANIMATION and FAKE PHOTO's from 'SPACE' the Earth is FLAT and we only have STEAM for power for the larger vehicles, including rockets to space.

BFR is simpler than Falcon Heavy from an engineering viewpoint. FH has had all the issues regarding central core loading and has essentially required a redesign of central Falcon core. The side cores essentially just require longeron upgrades. The software updates would also be somewhat interesting. I assume (this being somewhere along my expertise) that the central core is a master and the two side cores are slaves - becoming autonomous for landing upon separation. BFR is essentially an enlargement of F9. OK, so there are some fundamental differences... New rocket motors - Raptors instead of Merlins and new fuel system - Methane instead of RP1 (kerosene). Both fuel and oxidizer (oxygen) are super densified (i.e. cooled and liquified) so little change there. The main problems for BFR are those that occur when approaching the limits of materials. Obviously F9  pushes these boundaries - more in the Merlin motors than the rocket itself. Further over simplifying the BFR task, a rocket is essentially a structural cylinder that  contains the rocket fuel vessels, supports the payload and mounts the rocket motors and avionics. Really, you 'only' have to package 2 fuel tanks, some pipes, a couple of valves and a bit of avionics in the structural cylinder - all within the limits of material science at the lowest mass possible. The Raptor engines encompass most of the complexity of the overall problem and could (and probably do) obviate the need for external valves. I expect to see BFR (not BFS or BFT - tanker - notice 'RST') in 2018 (in some variant if not partially built) and I expect test flying 2019 - not from a conventional pad, but more 'just' hopping in Texas - McGregor initially and then most likely real testing from a proper pad in Boca Chica.

Technically you're not seeing the oxygen boiling off itself but the atmospheric water vapor quickly condensing on the cold oxygen. You can see clouds (minute water droplets) but gaseous nitrogen and oxygen (the two main constituents of Earth's atmosphere) are transparent

If you right-click on the youtube video of the SpaceX webcasts, and check the youtube "Stats for nerds" , you get the stats of the live transmission. Interesting fact, the time delay between 'real-life' and the video we see there live, is about 9100 miliseconds (9 seconds). Think about playing an online shooter with ping 9100. Not totally "live". But the same can be said for "live" tv which is probably also delayed by 1-2 seconds.. PS. this is not any criticism. Just something I observed and found interesting

My question is, when the falcon 9 is landing, the time between the entry burn and the landing burn, the rocket continues to slow down, even when the engines are off. How is the possible? During this NROL-76 launch webcast, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EzQpkQ1etdA, you can see that at 19:54, the entry burn has ended, and the landing burn hasnt started yet, but the rocket is decelerating. How is something that is plummeting through the sky slowing down with no wing/flaps/engines?

It's neither smoke nor steam, it's water condensation in the super-cold oxygen-rich air. You could have talked about it happening to cool down the rocket so that at launch the rocket is full of liquid ox for max power during the climb to space.

And fun fact, the reason why you see the bright orange flame from the Merlin main engine is due to the LOX/RP1 (liquid oxygen and highly refined kerosene), the liquid oxygen is not entirely ignited inside of the tank and some of it is actually ignited in the plume, hence the giant orange flame. A more complete burn inside of the engine will allow you to see the classic mach diamonds and a finer plume.

SLC-4 at Vandenberg is not able to support Falcon Heavy launches. While it was designed with Falcon Heavy in mind, that was back in the old "Falcon 9 v1.0" days, and the Falcon 9 "Full Thrust" based Falcon Heavy is a very different rocket, and would require significant upgrades. They may make those upgrades eventually, but if they do it'll be after the Iridium contract is finished, at the very earliest.
